ratings.question_text: Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.

What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I did not have any art background at all and felt very comfortable in this course.
Developed some skills in painting by practicing each week in class and gained a new perspective about contemporary abstract art through our professor's instruction
I learned much more about the shapes and shadows of objects we paint. We only painted with the colors black and white, which stabilized fundamentals.
I gained insight into some of the most basic materials involved in painting, including paint mixing, shade, brush strokes, and composition. I also got a chance to see some interesting paintings.
I gained valuable knowledge of painting techniques that improved the way that I approach art and conduct a painting.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Robert Storr is a great art teacher and storyteller. He has many connections to museums and famous artists (which he is one), and he tells us anecdotes of them and is able to strongly analyze their artwork. He also explains well on how to use different artists' styles to input into ours. Additionally, he played music during class, which was relaxing.

This is a great course. But taking it through zoom is a pretty poor substitute for in person learning. There were frequent technical difficulties. But it was low pressure, and a really nice way to round out a schedule during the pandemic.

The course was amazing as Professor Storr tried to engage us as much as possible due to the virtual format. He provided useful wisdom both in art and real life. I enjoyed the stories he would tell and the conversations he had before class started. One weakness would be that sometimes the instructions were unclear, but that was easily resolved by asking him on Zoom.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments:
The class was all on Zoom, which was incredibly difficult but unavoidable given the Yale mandate to socially distance and use online methods as much as possible. Instead of the professor being able to walk around and critique our paintings while we painted in a classroom, we had to paint and then hold them up through the Zoom camera. However, Rob and the TA did their best to critique our artwork, as well as pull up examples of pieces by artists.

A way to improve is being able to sit in a classroom (socially distanced, with masks on). This would probably work and be of minimal risk to the instructor and students since there are less than 15-20 people in the class. But of course, with virtual learning and not everyone in New Haven, it was not possible this semester.

It's really hard to say whether this class can ever be considered a success, at least to the same extent as it once might have been, in a world where we cannot paint in the same room and where we can only see each other's work through a webcam on a laptop. With that said, if anyone can squeeze the most out of circumstances like these, it's Robert Storr.
I believe in the circumstances, Professor Storr did the best possible and provided an exceptional course.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Yes, it is an incredibly fun and relaxing class. Painting Basics is a very much a gut with Robert Storr (not sure about other instructors).

If you want to learn the basics of wonderful, life affirming and enriching practice from someone who has dedicated his entire life to studying it, take this course. But maybe wait until you can do so in person. And make sure you like professors like Rob. He can be intimidating, but that's because he's an expert. Be confident and take creative risks and you'll be fine.
I would definitely recommend this course to another student as it was well organized for student learning and provided great feedback.
